lexUnit.name: insult.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: To act or speak in such a way as to spark offended feelings in another

sentence.text: ` They do n't insult you with weak dialogue or a stupid plot . "
Windsor whitewash insults all taxpayers
He has insulted me !
She had been rejected by co-op boards and insulted by fashion arbiters .
How often we confine faith and insult God by entertaining puny conceptions of him !
Manager Intikhab earned a severe reprimand for to journalists that his players had been ` insulted " by umpire Palmer 's handling of the sweater .
He feels they do n't appreciate Patrick , who was not really likeable because he drank rather too much and insulted people and all sorts of things .
Nor was he ready yet publicly to insult his queen .
` You 'll insult me once too often , Khan . "
Let them know that you have n't prepared , and you insult them even further .
Never before has he dared to question the sensornet or insult another officer so openly . "
You insult my intelligence with your crude methods !
“ No one insults my family and gets away with it . ”
They would insult each other without mercy but with great humour .

Gratitude that the Scottish Football Association and Scottish Rugby Union have apparently stopped insulting us with Scotland the Brave is not reason enough to allow them to inflict ` the people 's choice " upon us .
Earlier , he was accused of insulting the Africans by holding his nose because he could not stand the smell .
If you are insulted because of the name of Christ , you are blessed , because the Spirit of glory and of God rests on you .
But for a long time all the local shop-boys had insulted him because he wore the uniform of a charity-boy .
` So do n't insult me , my friend . "
I insulted him at the time .
And then he insulted Jean .
In 1963 , having perhaps insulted one Prime Minister too many in the run-up to a general election , TW3 was taken off the air , although it was stoutly defended by Hugh Greene .
I 'd be insulted if my colleagues had n't noticed . "
Tawell 's counsel , Fitzroy Kelly , had already insulted the jury 's intelligence by suggesting that prussic acid found in Sara 's body was due to eating too many apples .
` I would n't insult you by thinking I could learn enough in a couple of days .
In charge of the bar a man of scarlet face and furious character roared and insulted in an orgy of camp bonhomie .
It was the first time in her life that she had been openly insulted .
Was he insulted ?
Now shut up and stop insulting my staff . "
“ Do n't insult my intelligence ! ”
But will he be insulted ?
